title: Can a person be called a politician for just having strong political opinions and not seeking office? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: No. That’s a “pundit” or “hobbyist” or “activist” depending on their level of engagement and media platform. A politician is someone who either seeks elected office or serves at the top level of appointed office. The elected office thing is obvious. For appointed office, the Junior Vice Associate Undersecretary for Corn Subsidies may be technically “appointed” because the 1836 Absurdly Generous Corn Subsidies Act requires it, but they’re probably a career bureaucrat and not a politician in any meaningful sense. This stands in contrast to their boss’s boss’s boss’s boss, the Secretary of Agriculture, who likely is either (A) a wealthy-but-at-least-tangentially-knowledgeable campaign contributor (this is before the Trump era), (B) a former state-level officeholder who’s won several elections and is looking for an interrim gig until the current Governor’s or Senator’s term is up, or (C) a career bureaucrat who rose so high they finally had to start actually playing politics in order to get any higher. In any case, the Sec-Ag is now a full-on politician, because while they may be appointed and have no formal electoral accountability, their boss the President does, and will happily subject them to all the usual political games and public opinion.

Can a person be called a politician for just having strong political opinions and not seeking office? The answer is “no”. One becomes a “politician” upon holding, or at least running for, a political office. Even those who work closely with office holders and/or candidates are not themselves “politicians” - they are staffers, handlers, etc. I, for one, have held “strong political opinions” along the way, but “politician” is not an adjective that is/was used to describe me. Just like having a strong interest in genetics doesn’t make one a geneticist, having “strong political opinions” does not make one a politician. A layperson with “strong political opinions” might qualify to be considered an “activist” or perhaps a “partisan”, but not a “politician”.
I don’t think so. That person has a right to opinion. Getting elected to state or national office earns one the dubious distinction to be called “politician”.
The descriptive word that you are looking for is, “loudmouth”. There’s one sat in a corner in every bar in every country.
